stork.feather

Class Resource<S extends Session<S,R>,R extends Resource<S,R>>

  • java.lang.Object
    • stork.feather.Resource<S,R>
  • Type Parameters:
    S - The type of Session that can operate on this Resource.
    R - The type of Resources this Resource can be selected from or produce through selection. Generally, for a subclass, this is the subclass itself.
    Direct Known Subclasses:
    AnonymousResource, FTPResource, HTTPBody, HTTPResource, IRODSResource, LocalResource

    public class Resource<S extends Session<S,R>,R extends Resource<S,R>>
extends Object
    A virtual representation of a physical resource. The resource(s) represented by a Resource object may be a single resource (such as a file or directory) or a set thereof (such as a directory tree or files matching a pattern). The existence of a Resource object does not guarantee the existence or accessibility of the resource(s) it represents. In particular, creating a Resource object does not

    A Resource should be thought of as a placeholder for or reference to a physical resource, with a Session as the entity responsible for providing access it to the concrete resource(s) it represents. A Resource object should not have any allocation state associated with it. Instead, such state should be maintained by the Session the Resource is selected through.

    In general, a Resource represents a selection path from a top-level Resource (typically a Session) to one or many Resources representing subresources. This top-level Resource is known as the root. If a Resource represents exactly one physical resource, it is called a singleton Resource. The trunk of a Resource is the first singleton Resource encountered when traversing backwards to the root.

    All of the methods specified by this interface should return immediately. In the case of methods that return Bells, the result should be determined asynchronously and given to the caller through the returned Bell. Implementations that do not support certain operations are allowed to throw an UnsupportedOperationException.

    See Also:
    Session

      • name

        public String name()
        Get the unencoded name of this Resource.

      • isRoot

        public final boolean isRoot()
        Return whether or not this is a root Resource.
        Returns:
        true if this is a root Resource; false otherwise.

      • trunk

        public final R trunk()
        Return the trunk of this Resource. That is, the nearest singleton parent Resource.
        Returns:
        The first singleton ancestor of this Resource.

      • isSingleton

        public final boolean isSingleton()
        Check if this is a singleton Resource. That is, a Resource that identifies exactly one physical resource.
        Returns:
        true if this is a singleton Resource; false otherwise.

      • reselectOn

        public R reselectOn(S session)
        Reselect this Resource through an equivalent Session. Assuming session is actually equivalent to this Resource's Session, the returned Resource will refer to the same physical resource. This can, for instance, be used to select the same Resource through an already established Session.
        Parameters:
        session - the session to reselect this resource on.
        Returns:
        An equivalent Resource which can be accessed through session.
        Throws:
        NullPointerException - if session is null.
        IllegalArgumentException - if session is not equivalent to this Resource's Session.

      • uri

        public URI uri()
        Get a URI associated with this resource.
        Returns:
        A URI which identifies this resource.

      • select

        public final R select(String name)
        Select a subresource relative to this resource.
        Parameters:
        name - the literal name of a subresource to select.
        Returns:
        A subresource of this resource.

      • select

        public R select(Path path)
        Select a subresource relative to this Resource using path.
        Parameters:
        path - the path to the subresource, relative to this Resource.
        Returns:
        A subresource relative to this Resource.

      • initialize

        public final Bell<R> initialize()
        Initialize the Session associated with this Resource to perform operations on this Resource. Implementors should call this themselves in the method body of any operation that requires Session initialization (for example, a control channel connection) to ensure that the associated Session is ready to operate. This can also be used outside the framework to "warm up" the Resource in anticipation of future use. The returned Bell will ring when initialization is complete, indicating that Resource implementations are allowed to perform the operation through the Session.
        Returns:
        (via bell) This Resource once it has been initialized to operate on this Resource.

      • stat

        public Bell<Stat> stat()
        Get metadata for this Resource.
        Returns:
        (via bell) A Stat containing resource metadata.
        Throws:
        Exception - (via bell) if there was an error retrieving metadata for the Resource.
        UnsupportedOperationException - if metadata retrieval is not supported.

      • list

        public Emitter<String> list()
        Get a listing of names of sub-Resources under this Resource.
        Returns:
        An Emitter that emits Resource names.
        Throws:
        UnsupportedOperationException - if listing is not supported.

      • mkdir

        public Bell<R> mkdir()
        Create this resource as a directory on the storage system. If the resource cannot be created, or already exists and is not a directory, the returned Bell will be resolved with an Exception.
        Returns:
        (via bell) this Resource if successful.
        Throws:
        Exception - (via bell) if the directory could not be created or already exists and is not a directory.
        UnsupportedOperationException - if creating directories is not supported.

      • delete

        public Bell<R> delete()
        Delete the Resource from the storage system. If the resource cannot be removed, the returned Bell will be resolved with an Exception.
        Returns:
        (via bell) null if successful.
        Throws:
        Exception - (via bell) if the resource could not be fully removed.
        UnsupportedOperationException - if removal is not supported.

      • sink

        public Sink<R> sink()
        Return a Sink that will drain data for this Resource. Any connection operation, if necessary, should begin asynchronously as soon as this method is called.
        Returns:
        A Sink which drains Slices to this Resource.
        Throws:
        Exception - (via bell) if opening the Sink fails.
        UnsupportedOperationException - if this Resource does not support writing.

      • tap

        public Tap<R> tap()
        Return a Tap that will emit data from this Resource. Any connection operation, if necessary, should begin asynchronously as soon as this method is called.
        Returns:
        (via bell) A Tap which emits Slices from this Resource.
        Throws:
        Exception - (via bell) if opening the Tap fails.
        UnsupportedOperationException - if this Resource does not support reading.

      • transferTo

        public <D extends Resource<?,D>> Transfer<R,D> transferTo(D resource)
        Initiate a transfer from this Resource to resource using whatever method is deemed most appropriate by the implementation. The implementation should try to transfer this Resource as efficiently as possible, and so should inspect the destination Resource to determine if more efficient alternatives to proxy transferring can be done. This method should perform a proxy transfer as a catch-all last resort.
        Parameters:
        resource - the destination resource to transfer this resource to
        Returns:
        A Transfer on success. The returned Transfer object can be used to control and monitor the transfer.
        Throws:
        UnsupportedOperationException - if the direction of transfer is not supported by one of the resources.
        NullPointerException - if resource is null.
